Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Mozart! Mozart! Mozart. Forgive me! Forgive your assassin! Mozart!

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Show some mercy! I beg you. I beg you! Show mercy to a guilty man!

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: Open the door, Signore! Please! Be good now! We've brought you something special. Something you're going to love.

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: Signore Salieri! Open the door. Come now. Be good!

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Mozart! Mozart! I confess it! Listen! I confess!

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Mozart! Mozart! I cannot bear it any longer! I confess! I confess what I did! I'm guilty! I killed you! Sir I confess! I killed you!

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Mozart, perdonami! Forgive your assassin! Piet! Piet! Forgive your assassin! Forgive me! Forgive! Forgive!

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: That's all right, Signore! He heard you! He forgave you! He wants you to go inside now and shut the window!

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: Come on, Signore! Look what I have for you! I can't give it to you from down here, can I?

Speaker: bystander
Dialogue: Who is that?

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: No one, sir. He'll be all right. Poor man. He's a little unhappy, you know.

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: Did he open?

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: Here I am, Signore. Now open the door.

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: Mmmm - this is good! This is the most delicious thing I ever ate, believe me! Signore, you don't know what you're missing! Mmmm!

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: Now that's enough, Signore! Open!

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: If you don't open this door, we're going to eat everything. There'll be nothing left for you. And I'm not going to bring you anything more.

Speaker: doctor gulden
Dialogue: He's going to live. It's much harder to cut your throat than most people imagine.

Speaker: doctor gulden
Dialogue: Here we are. Do you wish me to come in with you?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: No, Doctor. Thank you.

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Herr Salieri?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: I am Father Vogler. I am a Chaplain here. I thought you might like to talk to someone.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: You tried to take your life. You do remember that, don't you?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: In the sight of God that is a sin.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Do you understand that you have sinned? Gravely.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Leave me alone.

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: I cannot leave alone a soul in pain.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Do you know who I am? You never heard of me, did you?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: That makes no difference. All men are equal in God's eyes.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Are they?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Offer me your confession. I can offer you God's forgiveness.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: I do not seek forgiveness.

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: My son, there is something dreadful on your soul. Unburden it to me. I'm here only for you. Please talk to me.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: How well are you trained in music?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: I know a little. I studied it in my youth.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Here in Vienna.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Then you must know this.

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: I can't say I do. What is it?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: I'm surprised you don't know. It was a very popular tune in its day. I wrote it. How about this?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: This one brought down the house when we played it first.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: I regret it is not too familiar.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Can you recall no melody of mine? I was the most famous composer in Europe when you were still a boy. I wrote forty operas alone. What about this little thing?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Oh, I know that! That's charming!  I didn't know you wrote that.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: I didn't. That was Mozart. Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. You know who that is?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Of course. The man you accuse yourself of killing.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Ah - you've heard that?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: All Vienna has heard that.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: And do they believe it?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Is it true?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Do you believe it?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Should I?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: For God's sake, my son, if you have anything to confess, do it now! Give yourself some peace!

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Do you hear me?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: He was murdered, Father! Mozart! Cruelly murdered.

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Yes? Did you do it?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: He was my idol! I can't remember a time when I didn't know his name! When I was only fourteen he was already famous. Even in Legnago - the tiniest town in Italy - I knew of him.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Suddenly he was dead. Just like that! And my life changed forever. My mother said, Go. Study music if you really want to. Off with you! And off I went as quick as I could and never saw Italy again. Of course, I knew God had arranged it all; that was obvious. One moment I was a frustrated boy in an obscure little town. The next I was here, in Vienna, city of musicians, sixteen years old and studying under Gluck! Gluck, Father. Do you know who he was? The greatest composer of his time. And he loved me! That was the wonder. He taught me everything he knew. And when I was ready, introduced me personally to the Emperor! Emperor Joseph - the musical king!  Within a few years I was his court composer. Wasn't that incredible? Imperial Composer to His Majesty! Actually the man had no ear at all, but what did it matter? He adored my music, that was enough. Night after night I sat right next to the Emperor of Austria, playing duets with him, correcting the royal sight-reading. Tell me, if you had been me, wouldn't you have thought God had accepted your vow? And believe me, I honoured it. I was a model of virtue. I kept my hands off women, worked hours every day teaching students, many of them for free, sitting on endless committees to help poor musicians - work and work and work, that was all my life. And it was wonderful! Everybody liked me. I liked myself. I was the most successful musician in Vienna. And the happiest. Till he came. Mozart.

Speaker: arco
Dialogue: Mozart is not here.

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: Where is he?

Speaker: arco
Dialogue: They're looking for him, Your Grace.

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: We'll start without him.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Miaouw! Miaouw! Mouse-wouse? It's Puss-wuss, fangs-wangs. Paws-claws. Pounce-bounce!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Stop it. Stop it!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Stop it!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I am! I am! I'm stopping it - slowly. You see! Look, I've stopped. Now we are going back.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: No! No! No!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes! Back! Back! Listen - don't you know where you are?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: We are in the Residence of the Fartsbishop of Salzburg.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Fartsbishop!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Your Grace, I've got something to tell you. I want to complain about this man.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Go ahead, tell him. Tell them all. They won't understand you anyway.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Because here everything goes backwards. People walk backwards, dance backwards, sing backwards, and talk backwards.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: That's stupid.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Why? People fart backwards.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Do you think that's funny?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes, I think it's brilliant. You've been doing it for years.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Oh, ha, ha, ha.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Sra-I'm-sick! Sra-I'm sick!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Yes, you are. You're very sick.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: No, no. Say it backwards, shit-wit. Sra-I'm-sick Say it backwards!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Sra-I'm-sick. Sick - kiss I'm - my Kiss my! Sra-I'm-sick - Kiss my arse!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Em iram! Em iram!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: No, I'm not playing this game.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: No, this is serious. Say it backwards.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Just say it - you'll see. It's very serious. Em iram!  Em iram!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Iram - marry Em - marry me! No, no! You're a fiend. I'm not going to marry a fiend. A dirty fiend at that.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Ui-vol-i-tub!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Tub - but i-tub - but I vol - love but I love ui - You. I love you!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Tish-I'm tee. What's that?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Tish-I'm-tee.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Eat

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Eat my - ah!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: My music! They've started! They've started without me!

Speaker: arco
Dialogue: Follow me, please. The Archbishop would like a word.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Certainly!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Well, I think that went off remarkably well, don't you?

Speaker: arco
Dialogue: Indeed.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: These Viennese certainly know good music when they hear it.

Speaker: arco
Dialogue: His Grace is very angry with you.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: arco
Dialogue: You are to come in here and ask his pardon.

Speaker: arco
Dialogue: Your Grace.

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: Ah, Mozart. Why?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Why what, sir?

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: Why do I have to be humiliated in front of my guests by one of my own servants?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Humiliated?

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: How much provocation am I to endure from you? The more license I allow you, the more you take.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: If His Grace is not satisfied with me, he can dismiss me.

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: I wish you to return immediately to Salzburg. Your father is waiting for you there patiently. I will speak to you further when I come.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: No, Your Grace! I mean with all humility, no. I would rather you dismissed me. It's obvious I don't satisfy.

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: Then try harder, Mozart. I have no intention of dismissing you. You will remain in my service and learn your place. Go now.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Excuse me!

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Why?  Would God choose an obscene child to be His instrument? It was not to be believed! This piece had to be an accident. It had to be!

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: How good is he, this Mozart?

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: He's remarkable, Majesty. I heard an extraordinary serious opera of his last month. Idomeneo, King of Crete.

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: Tiresome?

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: Majesty, I thought it the most promising work I've heard in years.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah-ha. Well then, we should make some effort to acquire him. We could use a good German composer in Vienna, surely?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: I agree, Majesty, but I'm afraid it's not possible. The young man is still in the pay of the Archbishop.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Very small pay, I imagine. I'm sure he could be tempted with the right offer. Say, an opera in German for our National Theatre.

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: Excellent, sire!

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah-ha. What do you say, Chamberlain?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: In my opinion, it is time we had a piece in our own language, sir. Plain German. For plain people.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah-ha. Kapellmeister?

Speaker: bonno
Dialogue: Majesty, I must agree with Herr Dirretore. Opera is an Italian art, solamente. German is - scusate - too bruta for singing, too rough.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah-ha. Court Composer, what do you say?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I think it is an interesting notion to keep Mozart in Vienna, Majesty. It should really infuriate the Archbishop beyond measure - if that is your Majesty's intention.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: You are cattivo, Court Composer.  I want to meet this young man. Chamberlain, arrange a pleasant welcome for him.

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well. There it is.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Si.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Ah! Here she comes. Fraulein Lorl, good morning.

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Good morning, sir.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: What have you got for me today? Let me see.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Ah-ha! Siena macaroons - my favourites. Give my best thanks to the baker.

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: I will, sir.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Thank you. Are you well today, Fraulein Lorl?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Yes, thank you, sir.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Bene! Bene!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Grazie, Signore.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: And the other one?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: And the other one?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, they're both so beautiful, I can't decide. Why don't I have two heads?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Good, good, good.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Good morning, gentlemen.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well, what do you have for me today?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Your Majesty, Herr Mozart -

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Yes, what about him?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: He's here.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah-ha. Well. There it is. Good.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Majesty, I hope you won't think it improper, but I have written a little March of Welcome in his honour.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: What a charming idea. May I see?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: It's just a trifle, of course.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: May I try it?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Majesty.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Delightful, Court Composer. Would you permit me to play it as he comes in?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: You do me too much honour, Sire.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Let's have some fun.  Bring in Herr Mozart, please. But slowly, slowly. I need a minute to practice.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: A-flat, Majesty.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah-ha!

Speaker: majordomo
Dialogue: Herr Mozart.

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Well done, Sire!

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Gentlemen, gentlemen, a little less enthusiasm, I beg you. Ah, Mozart.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Your Majesty!

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: No, no, please! It is not a holy relic.  He was giving the most brilliant little concert here. As he got off the stool, he slipped and fell. My sister Antoinette helped him up herself, and do you know what he did? Jumped straight into her arms and said, Will you marry me, yes or no?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: You know all these gentlemen, I'm sure.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: The Baron Von Swieten.

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: I'm a great admirer of yours, young man. Welcome.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, thank you.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: The Director of our Opera. Count Orsini-Rosenberg.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh sir, yes! The honour is mine. Absolutely.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: And here is our illustrious Court Composer, Herr Salieri.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Finally! Such an immense joy. Diletto straordinario!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I know your work well, Signore. Do you know I actually composed some variations on a melody of yours?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Mio caro Adone.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Ah!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: A funny little tune, but it yielded some good things.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: And now he has returned the compliment. Herr Salieri composed that March of Welcome for you.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Really? Oh, grazie, Signore! Sono commosso! E un onore per mo eccezionale. Compositore brilliante e famossissimo!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: My pleasure.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well, there it is. Now to business. Young man, we are going to commission an opera from you. What do you say?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Majesty!

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Did we vote in the end for German or Italian?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Did we?

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: I don't think it was really decided, Director.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, German! German! Please let it be German.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Why so?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Because I've already found the most wonderful libretto!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I - I don't think you have, Herr Director. Not yet. I mean, it's quite n - Of course, I'll show it to you immediately.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well, what is it about? Tell us the story.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: It's actually quite amusing, Majesty. It's set - the  whole thing is set in a - in a -

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Yes, where?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: In a Pasha's Harem, Majesty. A Seraglio.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah-ha.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Well not especially. It can be in Turkish, if you really want. I don't care.

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: My dear fellow, the language is not finally the point. Do you really think that subject is quite appropriate for a national theatre?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Why not? It's charming. I mean, I don't actually show concubines exposing their! their! It's not indecent!  It's highly moral, Majesty. It's full of proper German virtues. I swear it. Absolutely!

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well, I'm glad to hear that.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Excuse me, Sire, but what do you think these could be? Being a foreigner, I would love to learn.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Cattivo again, Court Composer. Well, tell him, Mozart. Name us a German virtue.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Love, Sire!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Ah, love! Well of course in Italy we know nothing about that.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: No, I don't think you do. I mean watching Italian opera, all those male sopranos screeching. Stupid fat couples rolling their eyes about! That's not love - it's just rubbish.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Majesty, you choose the language. It will be my task to set it to the finest music ever offered a monarch.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well, there it is. Let it be German.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah, this is yours.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Keep it, Sire, if you want to. It is already here in my head.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: What? On one hearing only?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I think so, Sire, yes.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Show me.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: The rest is just the same, isn't it?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: That really doesn't work, does it?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Did you try this? Wouldn't it be just a little more -?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Or this - yes, this! Better.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Grazie, Signore.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Madame Cavalieri is here for her lesson, sir.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Bene.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Maestro.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Well? How do you like it? It's Turkish. My hairdresser tells me everything's going to be Turkish this year!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Really? What else did he tell you today? Give me some gossip.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Well, I heard you met Herr Mozart.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Oh? News travels fast in Vienna.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: And he's been commissioned to write an opera. Is it true?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Is there a part for me?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: How do you know?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Well even if there is, I don't think you want to get involved with this one.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Well, do you know where it's set, my dear?

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: In a harem.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: A brothel.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: A Turkish brothel.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Turkish? Oh, if it's Turkish, that's different. I want to be in it.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: My dear, it will hardly enhance your reputation to be celebrated throughout Vienna as a singing prostitute for a Turk.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Oh. Well perhaps you could introduce us anyway.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Perhaps.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: What does he look like?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: You might be disappointed.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Looks and talent don't always go together, Katherina.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Looks don't concern me, Maestro. Only talent interests a woman of taste.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Since you are determined, Since you are determined, Calmly, with no ferment, Welcome - every pain and woe. Bind me then - compel me! Bind me then - compel me! Hurt me. Break me! Kill me! At last I shall be freed by death!

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Be freed at last by death! Be freed at last by death! At last I shall be freed By! Death!

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Understand, I was in love with the girl. Or at least in lust. I wasn't a saint. It took me the most tremendous effort to be faithful to my vow. I swear to you I never laid a finger on her. All the same, I couldn't bear to think of anyone else touching her - least of all the Creature.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Bravo, Madame. You are an ornament to our stage.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Majesty.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: And to you, Court Composer. Your pupil has done you great credit.

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: Let us pass, please! Let us pass at once! We're with the Emperor.

Speaker: flunky
Dialogue: I am sorry, Madame. It is not permitted.

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: Do you know who I am?  This is my daughter. I am Frau Weber. We are favoured guests!

Speaker: flunky
Dialogue: I am sorry, Madame, but I have my orders.

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: Call Herr Mozart! You call Herr Mozart immediately! This is insupportable!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Mother, please!

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: Go ahead, Constanze. Just ignore this fellow.  Go ahead, dear!

Speaker: flunky
Dialogue: I am sorry, Madame, but no! I cannot let anyone pass.

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: Young man, I am no stranger to theatres. I'm no stranger to insolence!

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well, Herr Mozart! A good effort. Decidedly that. An excellent effort! You've shown us something quite new today.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: It is new, it is, isn't it, Sire?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Yes, indeed.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: And German?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Oh, yes. Absolutely. German. Unquestionably!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: So then you like it? You really like it, Your Majesty?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Of course I do. It's very good. Of course now and then - just now and then - it gets a touch elaborate.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What do you mean, Sire?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well, I mean occasionally it seems to have, how shall one say?  How shall one say, Director?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Exactly. Very well put. Too many notes.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I don't understand. There are just as many notes, Majesty, as are required. Neither more nor less.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: My dear fellow, there are in fact only so many notes the ear can hear in the course of an evening. I think I'm right in saying that, aren't I, Court Composer?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes! yes! er, on  the whole, yes, Majesty.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: But this is absurd!

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: My dear, young man, don't take it too hard. Your work is ingenious. It's quality work. And there are simply too many notes, that's all. Cut a few and it will be perfect.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Which few did you have in mind, Majesty?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well. There it is.

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: Wolfi! Wolfi, my dear!

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Majesty, this is Madame Weber. She is my landlady.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Enchanted, Madame.

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: Oh, Sire! such an honour! And, and, and these are my dear daughters. This is Constanze. She is the fiancee of Herr Mozart.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Really? How delightful. May I ask when you marry?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Well - Well we haven't quite received my father's consent, Your Majesty. Not entirely. Not altogether.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Excuse me, but how old are you?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Twenty-six.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well, my advice is to marry this charming young lady and stay with us in Vienna.

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: You see? You see? I've told him that, Your Majesty, but he won't listen to me.

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: Oh, Your Majesty, you give such wonderful - such impeccable - such royal advice. I - I - May I?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well. There it is. Strack.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Get some water!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Katherina! I'll tell you what I'm going to do. I'm going to write another aria for you. Something even more amazing for the second act. I have to get some water. Her mother is lying on the stage.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Don't bother!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Don't bother.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I'll be right back.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Are you all right?

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: Ah, what an evening! What a wise man we have for an Emperor. Oh, my children!  Now I want you to write your father exactly what His Majesty said.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: You should really go home now, Frau Weber. Your carriage must be waiting.

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: But aren't you taking us?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I have to talk to the singers.

Speaker: madame weber
Dialogue: That's all right; we'll wait for you. Just don't take all night.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Did you know? Had you heard?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: The marriage!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Well, what does it matter to you?

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Nothing! He can marry who he pleases. I don't give a damn.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: How was I? Tell me honestly.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: You were sublime.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: What did you think of the music?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Extremely clever.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Meaning you didn't like it.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh - excuse me!

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Is her mother still lying on the floor?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: No, she's fine.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: I'm so relieved.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Dear Mozart, my sincere congratulations.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Did you like it, then?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: How could I not?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: It really is the best music one can hear in Vienna today. Don't you agree?

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Is she a good fuck?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What??

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: I assume she's the virtuoso in that department. There can't be any other reason you'd marry someone like that.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: Come in!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Excuse me, Wolfi. Mama is not feeling very well. Can we leave now?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: No, no, no, no. You can't take him away now. This is his night. Won't you introduce us, Wolfgang?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Excuse us, Fraulein. Good night, Signore.

Speaker: cavalieri
Dialogue: You really are full of surprises, aren't you? You are quite extraordinary, you little shit!

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: It was incomprehensible. What was God up to? Here I was denying all my natural lust in order to deserve God's gift and there was Mozart indulging his in all directions - even though engaged to be married! - and no rebuke at all! Was it possible I was being tested? Was God expecting me to offer forgiveness in the face of every offense, no matter how painful? That was very possible. All the same, why him? Why use Mozart to teach me lessons in humility? My heart was filling up with such hatred for that little man. For the first time in my life I began to know really violent thoughts. I couldn't stop them.

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Did you try?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Every day. Sometimes for hours I would pray!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Please! Please! Send him away, back to Salzburg. For his sake as well as mine.

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: No! I won't have him back.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: But he needs to be here in Salzburg, Your Grace. He needs me and he needs you. Your protection, your understanding.

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: Hardly.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Oh sir, yes! He's about to make the worst mistake of his life. Some little Viennese slut is trying to trick him into marriage. I know my son. He is too simple to see the trap - and there is no one there who really cares for him.

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: I'm not surprised. Money seems to be more important to him than loyalty or friendship. He has sold himself to Vienna. Let Vienna look out for him.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Sir -

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: Your son is an unprincipled, spoiled, conceited brat.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Yes, sir, that's the truth. But don't blame him. The fault is mine. I was too indulgent with him. But not again. Never again, I promise! I implore you - let me bring him back here. I'll make him give his word to serve you faithfully.

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: And how will you make him keep it?

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Oh, sir, he's never disobeyed me in anything. Please, Your Grace, give him one more chance.

Speaker: colloredo
Dialogue: You have leave to try.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Oh, Your Grace - I thank Your Grace! I thank you!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: And will you, Constanze Weber, take this man, Wolfgang to be your lawful husband?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: I now pronounce you man and wife.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Good morning, Court Composer. This is my niece, the Princess Elizabeth.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Your Highness.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: She has asked me to advise her on a suitable musical instructor. I think I've come up with an excellent idea.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Oh, Your Majesty, it would be such a tremendous honour!

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: I'm thinking about Herr Mozart. What is your view?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: An interesting idea, Majesty. But -

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: You already commissioned an opera from Mozart.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: And the result satisfies.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes, of course. My concern is to protect you from any suspicion of favouritism.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah-ha. Favouritism. But I so want Mozart.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I'm sure there is a way, Majesty. Some kind of a little contest. I could perhaps put together a small Committee, and I could see to it naturally that it will select according to Your Majesty's wishes.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: You please me, Court Composer. A very clever idea.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Sire.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well. There it is.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What is this, Herr Chamberlain?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: What is what?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Why do I have to submit samples of my work to some stupid committee? Just to teach a sixteen-year-old girl.

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Because His Majesty wishes it.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Is the Emperor angry with me?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: On the contrary.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Then why doesn't he simply appoint me to the post?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Mozart, you are not the only composer in Vienna.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: No, but I'm the best.

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: A little modesty would suit you better.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Who is on this committee?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Kapellmeister Bonno, Count Orsini- Rosenberg and Court Composer Salieri.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Naturally, the Italians! Of course! Always the Italians!

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Mozart -

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: They hate my music. It terrifies them. The only sound Italians understand is banality. Tonic and dominant, tonic and dominant, from here to Resurrection!  Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Anything else is morbid.

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Mozart -

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Show them one interesting modulation and they faint. Ohime! Morbidezza! Morbidezza! Italians are musical idiots and you want them to judge my music!

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Look, young man, the issue is simple. If you want this post, you must submit your stuff in the same way as all your colleagues.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Must I? Well, I won't! I tell you straight: I will not!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I think you're mad! You're really mad!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, leave me alone.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: One royal pupil and the whole of Vienna will come flocking. We'd be set up for life!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: They'll come anyway. They love me here.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: No, they will not. I know how things work in this city.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh yes? You always know everything.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Well, I'm not borrowing any more money from my mother, and that's that!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: You borrowed money from your mother?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Well, don't do that again!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: How are we going to live, Wolfi? Do you want me to go into the streets and beg?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Don't be stupid.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: All they want to see is your work. What's wrong with that?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Shut up! Just shut up! I don't need them.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: This isn't pride. It's sheer stupidity!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir, there is a lady who insists on talking to you.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Who is she?

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: She didn't say. But she says it's urgent.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Excuse me, my dear.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Excellency!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Madame. How can I help you?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Frau Mozart?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: That's right, Your Excellency. I've come on behalf of my hus band. I'm - I'm bringing some samples of his work so he can be considered for the royal appointment.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: How charming.  But why did he not come himself?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: He's terribly busy, sir.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I will look at them, of course, the moment I can. It will be an honour. Please give him my warmest.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Would it be too much trouble, sir, to ask you to look at them now? While I wait.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I'm afraid I'm not at leisure this very moment. Just leave them with me. I assure you they will be quite safe.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I - I really cannot do that, Your Excellency. You see, he doesn't know I'm here.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: My husband is a proud man, sir. He would be furious if he knew I'd come.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Then he didn't send you?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: No, sir. This is my own idea.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Sir, we really need this job. We're desperate. My husband spends far more than he can ever earn. I don't mean he's lazy - he's not at all - he works all day long. It's just! he's not practical. Money simply slips through his fingers, it's really ridiculous, Your Excellency. I know you help musicians. You're famous for it. Give him just this one post. We'd be forever indebted!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Let me offer you some refreshment. Do you know what these are?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Cappezzoli di Venere. Nipples of Venus. Roman chestnuts in brandied sugar. Won't you try one? They're quite surprising.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Oh! They're wonderful.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Thank you very much, Your Excellency.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Don't keep calling me that. It puts me at such a distance. I was not born a Court Composer, you know. I'm from a small town, just like your husband.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Are you sure you can't leave that music, and come back again? I have other things you might like.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: That's very tempting, but it's impossible, I'm afraid. Wolfi would be frantic if he found those were missing. You see, they're all originals.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Originals?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: These are originals?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Yes, sir. He doesn't make copies.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Astounding! It was actually beyond belief. These were first and only drafts of music yet they showed no corrections of any kind. Not one. Do you realize what that meant?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: He'd simply put down music already finished in his head. Page after page of it, as if he was just taking dictation. And music finished as no music is ever finished.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Is it no good?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: It is miraculous.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Oh yes. He's really proud of his work.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: So, will you help him?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Tomorrow night I dine with the Emperor. One word from me and the post is his.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Oh, thank you, sir!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Come back tonight.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Tonight?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Alone.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Some service deserves service in return. No?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Isn't it obvious?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: It's a post all Vienna seeks. If you want it for your husband, come tonight.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: But! I'm a married woman!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Then don't. It's up to you. Not to be vague, that is the price.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Yes, Father. Yes! So much for my vow of chastity. What did it matter? Good, patient, hard-working, chaste - what did it matter? Had goodness made me a good composer? I realized it absolutely then - that moment: goodness is nothing in the furnace of art. And I was nothing to God.

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: You cannot say that!

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: No? Was Mozart a good man?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: God's ways are not yours. And you are not here to question Him. Offer him the salt of penitence. He will give you back the bread of eternal life. He is all merciful. That is all you need to know.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: All I ever wanted was to sing to Him. That's His doing, isn't it? He gave me that longing - then made me mute. Why? Tell me that. If He didn't want me to serve Him with music, why implant the desire, like a lust in my body, then deny me the talent? Go on, tell me! Speak for Him!

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: My son, no one can speak for God.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Oh? I thought you did so every day. So speak now. Answer me!

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: I do not claim to unravel the mysteries. I treasure them. As you should.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: There is no God of Mercy, Father. Just a God of torture.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Dear God, enter me now. Fill me with one piece of true music. One piece with your breath in it, so I know that you love me. Please. Just one. Show me one sign of your favour, and I will show mine to Mozart and his wife. I will get him the royal position, and if she comes, I'll receive her with all respect and send her home in joy. Enter me! Enter me! Please! Te imploro.

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: That lady is back, sir.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Show her in. Then go to bed.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Well, I'm here. My husband has gone to a concert. He didn't think I would enjoy it.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I do apologize for this afternoon. I behaved like a silly girl. Where shall we go?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Should we stay here? It's a charming room. I love these candlesticks. Were they here earlier? I didn't notice them I suppose I was too nervous.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Wolfgang was given some candlesticks by King George in England, but they were only wood. Oh, excuse me. Let's not talk about him. What do you think of this? It's real lace. Brussels.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Well, it's much too good for every day. I keep saying to Wolfi, don't be so extravagant. Presents are lovely, but we can't afford them. It doesn't do any good. The more I tell him, the more he spends. Oh, excuse me! There I go again.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Do you still want to look at this? Or don't we need to bother anymore? I imagine we don't, really.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Go! Go! Go!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Show this woman out!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: You shit! You shit! You rotten shit!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: What are you staring at?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Because You will not enter me, with all my need for you; because You scorn my attempts at virtue; because You choose for Your instrument a boastful, lustful, smutty infantile boy and give me for reward only the ability to recognize the Incarnation; because You are unjust, unfair, unkind, I will block You! I swear it! I will hinder and harm Your creature on earth as far as I am able. I will ruin Your Incarnation.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Stanzi! Stanzi! Stanzi-Manzi!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Sssh!

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: Stanzi-Manzi-Banzi-Wanzi!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Sssh! Stay here.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: Sssh! You're dishgrashful!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Stanzi? How's my mouse? Mouse-wouse? I'm back - puss-wuss is back!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Stanzi!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What's the matter? What is it? Stanzi!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Stop it now. Stop it. I've brought some friends to meet you. They're next door waiting. Do we have anything to eat? They're all starving.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Tell them to go away. I don't want to see anybody.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What's the matter with you?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Tell them to go!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Sssh. What is it? Tell me.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I love you! I love you!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I love you. Please stay with me. I'm frightened.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: I don't think you understand me, Court Composer.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Majesty, I did. Believe me, it was a most agonizing. decision. But finally, I simply could not recommend Herr Mozart.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Well, Sire, I made some inquiries in a routine way. I was curious to know why he had so few pupils. It is rather alarming.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Oh?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Majesty, I don't like to talk against a fellow musician.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Of course not.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I have to tell you, Mozart is not entirely to be trusted alone with young ladies.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: As a matter of fact, one of my own pupils - a very young singer - told me she was - er - well!

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Molested, Majesty. Twice, in the course of the same lesson.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah-ha. Well. There it is.

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: Sir, there is a Herr Mozart waiting for you in the salon.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: What does he want?

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: He didn't say, sir. I told him I didn't know when you would be back, but he insisted on waiting.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Come with me. And stay in the room.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Herr Mozart, what brings you here?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Your Excellency, you requested some specimens of my work. Here they are. I don't have to tell you how much I need your help. I truly appreciate your looking at these. I have pressures on me - financial pressures. As you know, I'm a married man now.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: So you are. How is your pretty wife?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: She is well. She is - well, actually, I'm about to become a father! She only told me last night. You are the first to know.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I'm flattered. And congratulations to you, of course.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: So you see, this post is very important to me right now.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Why didn't you come to me yesterday, Mozart? This is a most painful situation. Yesterday I could have helped you. Today, I can't.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Why? Here is the music. It's here. I am submitting it humbly. Isn't that what you wanted?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I have just come from the palace. The post has been filled.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Filled? That's impossible! They haven't even seen my work. I need this post. Please, can't you help me? Please!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: My dear Mozart, there is no one in the world I would rather help, but now it is too late.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Whom did they choose?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Herr Sommer.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Sommer? Herr Sommer? But the man's a fool! He's a total mediocrity.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: No, no, no: he has yet to achieve mediocrity.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: But I can't lose this post, I simply can't! Excellency, please. Let's go to the palace, and you can explain to the Emperor that Herr Sommer is an awful choice. He could actually do musical harm to the Princess!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: An implausible idea. Between you and me, no one in the world could do musical harm to the Princess Elizabeth.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Look, I must have pupils. Without pupils I can't manage.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: You don't mean to tell me you are living in poverty?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: No, but I'm broke. I'm always broke. I don't know why.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: It has been said, my friend, that you are inclined to live somewhat above your means.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: How can anyone say that? We have no cook, no maid. We have no footman. Nothing at all!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: How is that possible? You give concerts, don't you? I hear they are quite successful.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: They're stupendously successful. You can't get a seat. The only problem is none will hire me. They all want to hear me play, but they won't let me teach their daughters. As if I was some kind of fiend. I'm not a fiend!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Of course not.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Do you have a daughter?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I'm afraid not.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Well, could you lend me some money till you have one? Then I'll teach her for free. That's a promise. Oh, I'm sorry. I'm being silly. Papa's right - I should put a padlock on my mouth. Seriously, is there any chance you could manage a loan? Only for six months, eight at most. After that I'll be the richest man in Vienna. I'll pay you back double. Anything. Name your terms. I'm not joking. I'm working on something that's going to explode like a bomb all over Europe!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Ah, how exciting! Tell me more.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I'd better not. It's a bit of a secret.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Come, come, Mozart; I'm interested. Truly.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Actually, it's a big secret. Oh, this is delicious! What is it?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Cream cheese mixed with granulated sugar and suffused with rum. Crema al Mascarpone.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Ah. Italian?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Forgive me. We all have patriotic feelings of some kind.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Two thousand, two hundred florins is all I need A hundred? Fifty?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: What exactly are you working on?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I can't say. Really

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I don't think you should become known in Vienna as a debtor, Mozart. However, I know a very distinguished gentleman I could recommend to you. And he has a daughter. Will that do?

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Quiet! Quiet! Quiet! Down there, damn you.  Welcome to you. Pay no attention, they're impossible. Stop it, you willful things! Come this way. Just ignore them. They're perfectly harmless, just willful. I treat them just like my own children.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: And which one of them do you want me to teach?

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: What? Ha-ha! That's funny - I like it. Which one, eh? You're a funny fellow.  Hannah! Come this way.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Hannah!

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: You won't be teaching this one either. She's my wife.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Madame.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: This is Herr Mozart, my dear. The young man Herr Salieri recommended to teach our Gertrude. Where is she?

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: Upstairs.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Gertrude!

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: You can't be Herr Mozart!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I'm afraid I am.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Of course, it's him. Who do you think it is?

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: I've heard about you for ages! I thought you must be an old man.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Gertrude!

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: It's such an honour for us to have you here, Herr Mozart. And for Gertrude.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: People who know say the girl's got talent. You must judge for yourself. If you think she stinks, say so.

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: Michael, please! I'm sure you will find her most willing, Herr Mozart. She's really very excited. She's been preparing all morning.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: Ah, now! Here she comes.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Good morning, Fraulein Schlumberg.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Strudel, this is Herr Mozart. Say good morning.

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: Perhaps a little refreshment first? A little coffee, or a little chocolate?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I'd like a little wine, if you have it.

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: Wine?

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Quite right. He's going to need it.  Klaus! A bottle of wine. Prestissimo! Now let's go to it. I've been waiting all day for this.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Especially you, Dudelsachs - not one sound from you.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Come on, then. Up and at it!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Now, please play me something. Just to give me an idea. Anything will do.

Speaker: gertrude
Dialogue: I don't want you to stay.

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: That's all right, dear. Just go ahead, as if we weren't here.

Speaker: gertrude
Dialogue: But you are here.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Never mind, Strudel. It's part of music, getting used to an audience. Aren't I right, Herr Mozart?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Well, yes! on the whole. I suppose.  How long have you been playing, Fraulein?

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: Just one year.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Who was your teacher?

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: I was. But she quite outgrew the little I could show her.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Thank you, Madame.  Come on now - courage. Play me something you know.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Perhaps it would be better if we were left alone. I think we're both a little shy.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Nonsense. Strudel's not shy. She's just willful! You give into her now, you'll be sorry later. Strudel - play.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: I said play!

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: Michael!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Perhaps if I were to play a little first, it might encourage the Fraulein.  Why don't you let me try the instrument? All right?

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Stop that, Dudelsachs! Stop it at once!  Don't let him disturb you. He'll be all right. He's just a little willful too. Please, please - play. I beg you.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Stop it! STOP!

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: No, not you. I was talking to the dog. You keep playing. It's most important. He always howls when he hears music. We've got to break them of the habit. Play, please. Please!

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: That's it. Now keep going, just keep going.  Now you stop that noise, Dudelsachs, you stop it this instant! This instant, do you hear me? Keep going, Herr Mozart, that's it. Go on, go on!

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Good, good, good! Very good dog! Very, very good Dudelsachs.  Quick, quick, dear, bring his biscuit.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Now guess who's going to get a nice reward? Clever, clever Dudi.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: It's a miracle, Herr Mozart!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Well, I'm a good teacher. The next time you wish me to instruct another of your dogs, please let me know. Goodbye, Fraulein, goodbye, Madame! goodbye, Sir!

Speaker: frau schlumberg
Dialogue: What a strange young man.

Speaker: schlumberg
Dialogue: Yes. He is a little strange.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Papa! PAPA!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Why are you here?

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Am I not welcome?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Of course, welcome! Welcome ten thousand times. Papa! my Papa!

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: You're very thin. Does she not feed you, this wife of yours?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Feed? Well, of course she feeds me. She stuffs me like a goose all day long. She's the best cook in the world. I mean, since Mama. Just wait, you'll see.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Is she not here?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I don't know. Stanzi? Stanzi!

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Do you always live like this?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, yes. Oh, I mean no - not exactly like this. I mean today - just today, Stanzi - I remember now. She had to go - yes! She had to help her mother. Yes, she's like that. Her mother's a very sweet woman, you'll see.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh! I didn't know you were home. Stanzi, this is my father.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: We'll wait, we'll wait. Why don't you get up now, darling?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: She's very tired, poor creature. You know me: I'm a real pig. It's not so easy cleaning up after me.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Don't you have a maid?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh we could, if we wanted to, but Stanzi won't hear of it. She wants to do everything herself.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: How is your financial situation?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: It couldn't be better.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: That's not what I hear.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What do you mean? It's wonderful. Really, it's - it's marvelous! People love me here.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: They say you're in debt.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Who? Who says that? Now that's a malicious lie!

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: How many pupils do you have?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Pupils?

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: How many?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I don't know. It's not important. I mean, I don't want pupils. They get in the way. I've got to have time for composition.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Composition doesn't pay. You know that.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: This one will.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, let's not talk about it.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: It's a secret.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: You don't have secrets from me.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: It's too dangerous, Papa. But they're going to love it. Ah, there she is!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: My Stanzi - look at her! Isn't she beautiful? Come on now, confess, Papa. Could you want a prettier girl for a daughter?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Stop it, Wolfi. I look dreadful. Welcome to our house, Herr Mozart.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: He's not Herr Mozart. Call him Papa.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: I see that you're expecting.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Oh, yes.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: When, may I ask?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: In three months! Papa.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Isn't that marvelous? We're delighted.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Why didn't you mention it in your letters?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Didn't I? I thought I did. I'm sure I did.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: May I offer you some tea, Herr Mozart?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Tea? Who wants tea? Let's go out! This calls for a feast. You don't want tea, Papa. Let's go dancing. Papa loves parties, don't you?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Wolfi!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What? How can you be so boring? Tea!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Wolfi, I think your father's tired. I'll cook us something here.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Thank you. That'll be fine. Don't spend any money on me.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Why not? Oh, come, Papa! What better way could I spend it than on you? My kissable, missable, suddenly visible Papa!

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: No, no! You both lost. You both lost. You both have to forfeit. And the penalty is you must exchange your wigs.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: No, please! This is ridiculous! No, please!

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: No, really!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: This is just a game, Papa.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: This is just a game, Papa!

Speaker: bystanders
Dialogue: This is just a game, Papa!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh no, Papa, please! Don't spoil the fun. Come on. Here, take mine.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: Herr Mozart, why don't you name your son's penalty?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes, Papa, name it. Name it. I'll do anything you say!

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: I want you to come back with me to Salzburg, my son.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: What did he say? What did he say?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Papa, the rule is you can only give penalties that can be performed in the room.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: I'm tired of this game. Please play without me.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: But my penalty. I've got to have a penalty.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: I've got a good one. I've got the perfect one for you. Come over here.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: Now, I want you to play our tune - sitting backwards.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, that's really too easy. Any child can do that.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: And a fugue in the manner of Sebastian Bach.

Speaker: guests
Dialogue: Another! Do another! Someone else.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Give me a name. Who shall I do? Give me a name.

Speaker: guests
Dialogue: Gluck! Haydn! Frederic Handel!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Salieri! Do Salieri!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Now that's hard. That's very hard. For Salieri one has to face the right way around.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Go on. Mock me. Laugh, laugh!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Wolfi! Wolfgang!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: There's a young girl to see you.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What does she want?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Well, ask her!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: She won't talk to me. She says she has to speak to you.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, damn!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Are you Herr Mozart?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: My name is Lorl, sir. I'm a maidservant. I was asked to come here and offer my services to you.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: They'll be paid for by a great admirer or yours who wishes to remain anon - anonymous.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: What do you mean? What admirer?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: I can't tell you that, ma'am.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Are you saying that someone is paying you to be our maid and doesn't want us to know who he is?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Yes. I can live in or out just as you wish.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Papa, is this your idea?

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Mine?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Are you playing a trick on me?

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: I never saw this girl in my life.  Is this a kind of joke?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Not at all, sir. And I was told to wait for an answer.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Young woman, this won't do at all. My son can't possibly accept such an offer, no matter how generous, unless he knows who is behind it.

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: But I really can't tell you, sir.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Oh, this is ridiculous.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: What is ridiculous? Wolfi has many admirers in Vienna. They love him here. People send us gifts all the time.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: But you can't take her without reference. It's unheard of!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Well, this is none of your business.  Whoever sent you is going to pay, no?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: That's right, ma'am.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: So now we are going to let a perfect stranger into the house?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Who is we? Who is letting who?  Could you please wait outside?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Look, old man, you stay out of this. We spend a fortune on you, more than we can possibly afford, and all you do is criticize, morning to night. And then you think you can -

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Stanzi!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: No, it's right he should hear. I'm sick to death of it. We can't do anything right for you, can we?

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Never mind. You won't have to do anything for me ever again. I'm leaving!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Papa!

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Don't worry, I'm not staying here to be a burden.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: No one calls you that.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: She does. She says I sleep all day.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: And so you do! The only time you come out is to eat.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: And what do you expect? Who wants to walk out into a mess like this every day?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Oh, now I'm a bad housekeeper!

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: So you are! The place is a pigsty all the time.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Do you hear him? Do you?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: When can you start?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Right away, ma'am.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Good! Come in. You'll start with that room there.  It's filthy!

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Sorry, sorry! I'm sorry I spoke! I'm just a provincial from Salzburg. What do I know about smart Vienna? Parties all night, every night. Dancing and drinking like idiot children!

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: They're out every night, sir. Till all hours.

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Oh, thank you, sir.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Do any pupils come to the house?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Not that I've seen.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Then how does he pay for all this? Does he work at all?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Oh, yes, sir, all day long. He never leaves the house until evening. He just sits there, writing and writing. He doesn't even eat.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Really? What is it he's writing?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Oh, I wouldn't know that, sir.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Of course not. You're a good girl. You're very kind to do this. Next time you're sure they'll be out of the house, let me know, will you?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: Oh, thank you, sir!

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: I think I've found out about the money, sir.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes what?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: He kept seven snuff boxes in here. I could swear they were all gold. And now look there's only one left. And inside, sir, look - I counted them - tickets from the pawnshop. Six of them.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Where does he work?

Speaker: lorl
Dialogue: In there, sir.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Bravo, Mozart. Most charming. Yes, indeed. Clever man.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Thank you, Sire!

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: Well done, Mozart. Really quite fine.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Baron!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Majesty, may I ask you to do me the greatest favour?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: May I introduce my father? He is on a short visit here and returning very soon to Salzburg. He would so much like to kiss your hand. It would make his whole stay so memorable for him.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah! By all means.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Your Majesty.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Good evening.  We have met before, Herr Mozart.

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: That's right, Your Majesty. Twenty years ago. No, twenty-two! twenty- three! And I remember word for word what you said to me. You said - you said --

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Bravo?

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: No! Yes, 'bravo,' of course 'bravo'! Everybody always says 'bravo' when Wolfi plays. Like the King of England. When we played for the King of England, he got up at the end and said, 'Bravo! Bravo! Bravo!' three times. Three bravo's. And the Pope four! Four bravo's from the Holy Father, and one 'bellissimo.'

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Father -

Speaker: leopold
Dialogue: Hush! I'm talking to His Majesty. Your Majesty, I wish to express only one thing - that you who are the Father of us all, could teach our children the gratitude they owe to fathers. It is not for nothing that the Fifth Commandment tells us: 'Honour your Father and Mother, that your days may be long upon the earth.'

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah-ha. Well. There it is.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I've just learned something that might be of interest to you, Herr Director.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Mozart is writing a new opera. An Italian opera.

Speaker: bonno
Dialogue: Aie!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: And that's not all. He has chosen for his subject, Figaro. The Marriage of Figaro.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: bonno
Dialogue: What is this Marriage of Figaro?

Speaker: bonno
Dialogue: Hah!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I've seen the manuscript.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Never mind.

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: I know we banned this play, but frankly I can't remember why. Can you refresh my memory, Herr Director?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Oh yes, yes. And that was?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Ah.

Speaker: lackey
Dialogue: Herr Mozart.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Sit down, gentlemen, please.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Mozart, are you aware I have declared the French play of Figaro unsuitable for our theatre?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes, Sire.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Yet we hear you are making an opera from it. Is this true?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Who told you this, Majesty?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: It is not your place to ask questions. Is it true?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Well, yes, I admit it is.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Would you tell me why?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Well, Majesty, it is only a comedy.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: But, Your Majesty -

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Mozart, I am a tolerant man. I do not censor things lightly. When I do, I have good reason. Figaro is a bad play. It stirs up hatred between the classes. In France it has caused nothing but bitterness. My own dear sister Antoinette writes me that she is beginning to be frightened of her own people. I do not wish to see the same fears starting here.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Sire, I swear to Your Majesty, there's nothing like that in the story. I have taken out everything that could give offense. I hate politics.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: I think you are rather innocent, my friend. In these dangerous times I cannot afford to provoke our nobles or our people simply over a theatre piece.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: But, Majesty, this is just a frolic. It's a piece about love.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Ah, love again.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: But it's new, it's entirely new. It's so new, people will go mad for it. For example, I have a scene in the second act - it starts as a duet, just a man and wife quarreling. Suddenly the wife's scheming little maid comes in unexpectedly - a very funny situation. Duet turns into trio. Then the husband's equally screaming valet comes in. Trio turns into quartet. Then a stupid old gardener - quartet becomes quintet, and so on.  On and on, sextet, septet, octet! How long do you think I can sustain that?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: I have no idea.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Guess! Guess, Majesty. Imagine the longest time such a thing could last, then double it.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Well, six or seven minutes! maybe eight!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Twenty, sire! How about twenty? Twenty minutes of continuous music. No recitatives.

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: Mozart -

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Sire, only opera can do this. In a play, if more than one person speaks at the same time, it's just noise. No one can understand a word. But with music, with music you can have twenty individuals all talking at once, and it's not noise - it's a perfect harmony. Isn't that marvelous?

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: Mozart, music is not the issue here. No one doubts your talent. It is your judgment of literature that's in question. Even with the politics taken out, this thing would still remain a vulgar farce. Why waste your spirit on such rubbish?  Surely you can choose more elevated themes?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Elevated? What does that mean? Elevated! The only thing a man should elevate is - oh, excuse me. I'm sorry. I'm stupid. But I am fed up to the teeth with elevated things! Old dead legends! How can we go on forever writing about gods and legends?

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: Because they do. They go on forever - at least what they represent. The eternal in us, not the ephemeral. Opera is here to ennoble us. You and me, just as much as His Majesty.

Speaker: bonno
Dialogue: Bello! Bello, Barone. Veramente.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, bello, bello, bello! Come on now, be honest. Wouldn't you all rather listen to your hairdressers than Hercules? Or Horatius? Or Orpheus? All those old bores! people so lofty they sound as if they shit marble!

Speaker: von swieten
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Govern your tongue, sir! How dare you?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Forgive me, Majesty. I'm a vulgar man. But I assure you, my music is not.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: You are passionate, Mozart! But you do not persuade.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Sire, the whole opera is finished. Do you know how much work went into it?

Speaker: bonno
Dialogue: His Majesty has been more than patient, Signore.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: How can I persuade you if you won't let me show it?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Just let me tell you how it begins.

Speaker: von strack
Dialogue: Herr Mozart -

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: May I just do that, Majesty? Show you how it begins? Just that?

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Look! There's a servant, down on his knees. Do you know why? Not from any oppression. No, he's simply measuring a space. Do you know what for? His bed. His wedding bed to see if it will fit.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Incredible.

Speaker: bonno
Dialogue: Si, si! Veramente.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Well, gentlemen, so be it. In that case I think we should help Mozart all we can and do our best to protect him against the Emperor's anger.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: About the ballet.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Excuse me - didn't His Majesty specifically forbid ballet in his opera?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes, in the third act.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Certainly, Herr Director.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Five minutes, please!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes, but this is not a ballet. This is a dance at Figaro's wedding.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: But surely the Emperor didn't mean to prohibit dancing when it's part of the story.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What are you doing, Herr Director?

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: Herr Mozart.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Please! Please. I've no one else to turn to. Please!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Wolfgang, what is it? Sta calmo, per favore. What's the matter?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: It's unbelievable! The Director has actually ripped out a huge section of my music. Pages of it.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Really? Why?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I don't know. They say I've got to re-write the opera, but it's perfect as it is. I can't rewrite what's perfect. Can't you talk to him?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Why bother with Orsini-Rosenberg? He's obviously no friend of yours.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, I could kill him! I mean really kill him. I actually threw the entire opera on the fire, he made me so angry!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: You burned the score?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh no! My wife took it out in time.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: How fortunate.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: It's not fair that a man like that has power over our work.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: But there are those who have power over him. I think I'll take this up with the Emperor.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh, Excellency, would you?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: With all my heart, Mozart.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Thank you! Oh, thank you.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: No, no, no, Herr Mozart, please. It's not a holy relic.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: I'm sure I don't need to tell you I said nothing whatever to the Emperor. I went to the theatre ready to tell Mozart that His Majesty had flown into a rage when I mentioned the ballet, when suddenly, to my astonishment, in the middle of the third act, the Emperor - who never attended rehearsals - suddenly appeared.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: What is this? I don't understand. Is it modern?

Speaker: bonno
Dialogue: Majesty, the Herr Director, he has removed a balleto that would have occurred at this place.

Speaker: joseph
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: joseph

Dialogue: Oblige me.

Dialogue: So Figaro was produced in spite of me. And in spite of me, a wonder was revealed. One of the true wonders of art. The restored third act was bold and brilliant. The fourth was a miracle.

Dialogue: And then suddenly - a miracle!

Dialogue: Father, did you know what that meant? With that yawn I saw my defeat turn into a victory. And Mozart was lucky the Emperor only yawned once. Three yawns and the opera would fail the same night; two yawns, within a week at most. With one yawn the composer could still get -

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Nine performances! Nine! That's all it's had - and withdrawn.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I know; it's outrageous. Still, if the public doesn't like one's work one has to accept the fact gracefully.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: But what is it they don't like?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Well, I can speak for the Emperor. You made too many demands on the royal ear. The poor man can't concentrate for more than an hour and you gave him four.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What did you think of it yourself? Did you like it at all?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I think it's marvelous. Truly.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: It's the best opera yet written. I know it! Why didn't they come?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I think you overestimate our dear Viennese, my friend. Do you know you didn't even give them a good bang at the end of songs so they knew when to clap?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I know, I know. Perhaps you should give me some lessons in that.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I wouldn't presume. All the same, if it wouldn't be imposing, I would like you to see my new piece. It would be a tremendous honour for me.

Dialogue: Oh no, the honour would be all mine.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Grazie, mio caro, Wolfgang!

Dialogue: Grazie, a lei, Signor Antonio!

Dialogue: Well?

Dialogue: Sublime! Utterly sublime!

Dialogue: Mozart. It was good of you to come.

Dialogue: Did my work please you?

Dialogue: I never knew that music like that was possible.

Dialogue: You flatter me.

Dialogue: What's that? Oh!  Who gave you this? How much is it? Wolfi, who gave you this?

Dialogue: Yes.

Dialogue: The only thing that worried me was the actual killing. How does one do that? How does one kill a man? It's one thing to dream about it. It's very different when you have to do it, with your own hands.

Dialogue: Wolfi. Wolfi!

Dialogue: I hope so. I need it immediately.

Dialogue: What the devil is this? Requiem Mass? Does he think I'm in the funeral business?

Dialogue: Leave that alone!

Dialogue: Wolfi!

Dialogue: Put it down!

Dialogue: What is this?

Dialogue: Oh! I'm sorry! I'm sorry! What have you got for me? Is it finished?

Dialogue: Look, you little clown, do you know how many people I've hired for you? Do you know how many people are waiting?

Dialogue: Leave him alone!

Dialogue: Money! Money!

Dialogue: Now calm yourself. Calm. What's the matter with you?

Dialogue: I'm leaving. I'm not working there anymore. I'm scared!

Dialogue: Why? What has happened?

Dialogue: You don't know what it's like. Herr Mozart frightens me. He drinks all day, then takes all that medicine and it makes him worse.

Dialogue: What medicine?

Dialogue: I don't know. He has pains.

Dialogue: Where?
