Dialogue: What do you mean - now?

Speaker: papageno
Dialogue: Well, I don't know! I mean you're a delicious, delightful, delectable little bird, but don't you think you might be just a little tough?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What happened? Is it over?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I'm taking you home. You're not well.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: No, no. I have to get back. I have -

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Thank you. Go.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Papa! Papa!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Come now.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Where is your wife?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Not here! She's not well, either. She went to the Spa.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: You mean she's not coming back?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: You're so good to me. Truly. Thank you.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: No, please.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I mean to come to my opera. You are the only colleague who did.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I would never miss anything that you had written. You must know that.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: This is only a vaudeville.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Oh no. It is a sublime piece. The grandest operone. I tell you, you are the greatest composer known to me.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Do you mean that?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I have bad fancies. I don't sleep well anymore. Then I drink too much, and think stupid things.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Are you ill?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: The doctor thinks I am. But -

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I'm too young to be so sick.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Shall I answer it?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: No! No, it's him!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: The man. He's here.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: What man?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Tell him to go away. Tell him I'm still working on it. Don't let him in!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Wait! Ask him if he'd give me some money now. Tell him if he would, that would help me finish it.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Finish what?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: He knows. He knows!

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: Herr Salieri.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes, I am looking after him.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: Can we come in?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Well, he's sleeping now. Better not.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: But he's all right?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Oh, yes. He's just exhausted. He became dizzy, that's all. We should let him rest.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: Well, tell him we were here, won't you?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: And say everything went wonderfully. A triumph-de-luxe - say that! Tell him the audience shouted his name a hundred times.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Bene.

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: I'll call tomorrow.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes.  And congratulations to all of you. It was superb.

Speaker: actresses
Dialogue: Thank you! Thank you, Excellency!

Speaker: schikaneder
Dialogue: Oh, by the way, give him this. This is his share. That should cheer him up, eh?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes, indeed. Goodnight to you all now. It was perfection - truly!

Speaker: actresses
Dialogue: Goodnight, Your Excellency. Goodnight!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: He said to give you this. And if you finish the work by tomorrow night, he will pay you another hundred ducats.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Another? But that's too soon! Tomorrow night? It's impossible! Did he say a hundred?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes. Can I - could I help you, in any way?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Would you? Actually, you could.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: My dear friend, it would be my greatest pleasure.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: But you'd have to swear not to tell a soul. I'm not allowed.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: You know, it's all here in my head. It's just ready to be set down. But when I'm dizzy like this my eyes won't focus. I can't write.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Then, let us try together. I'd regard it as such an honour. Tell me, what is this work?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: A Mass. A Mass for the Dead.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I want to go!

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I want to go back to Vienna.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Now?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I feel wrong. I feel wrong being here.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Where did I stop?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: The end of the Recordare - Statuens in parte dextra.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: So now the Confutatis. Confutatis Maledictis. When the wicked are confounded. Flammis acribus addictis. How would you translate that?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Consigned to flames of woe.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Do you believe in it?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: A fire which never dies. Burning one forever?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Oh, yes.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Strange!

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Come. Let's begin.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Confutatis Maledictis.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: We ended in F Major?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: So now - A minor. Suddenly.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: The Fire.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: What time?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Common time.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Start with the voices. Basses first. Second beat of the first measure - A.  G-sharp, of course.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Third measure, second beat starting on E.  Do you have that?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Sing it back.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Good. Now the tenors. Fourth beat of the first measure - C.  All right?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Fourth measure, second beat - F.  Flam-mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis, flam- mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Now the orchestra. Second bassoon and bass trombone with the basses. Identical notes and rhythm.  The first bassoon and tenor trombone -

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Please! Just one moment.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: It couldn't be simpler.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: First bassoon and tenor trombone - what?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: With the tenors.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Also identical?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Exactly. The instruments to go with the voices. Trumpets and timpani, tonic and dominant.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: And that's all?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Oh no. Now for the Fire.  Strings in unison - ostinato on all - like this.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Second measure on B.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Do you have me?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Show me.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Good, good - yes! Put it down. And the next measures exactly the same, rising and rising - C to D to E, up to the dominant chord. Do you see?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: That's wonderful!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes, yes - go on. The Voca Me. Suddenly sotto voce. Write that down: sotto voce, pianissimo. Voca me cum benedictis. Call me among the blessed.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: C Major. Sopranos and altos in thirds. Altos on C. Sopranos above.  Vo-ca, vo-ca me, vo-ca me cum be-ne- dic-tis.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Sopranos up to F on the second 'Voca'?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Yes, and on 'dictis'.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: And underneath, just violins - arpeggio.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: The descending scale in eighth notes, and then back suddenly to the fire again.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: And that's it. Do you have it?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: You go fast!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Do you have it?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Then let me hear it. All of it. The whole thing from the beginning - now!

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Do you want to rest a bit?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Oh no. I'm not tired at all.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: We'll stop for just a moment. Then we'll do the Lacrimosa.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I can keep going, I assure you. Shall we try?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: Would you stay with me while I sleep a little?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I'm not leaving you.

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I am so ashamed.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: mozart
Dialogue: I was foolish. I thought you did not care for my work - or me. Forgive me. Forgive me!

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Your husband is ill, ma'am. He took sick. I brought him home.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Why you?

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: I was at hand.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Well, thank you very much. You can go now.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: He needs me, ma'am.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: No, he doesn't. And I don't want you here. Just go, please.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: He asked me to stay.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: And I'm asking you -

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Wolfi, I'm back. I'm still very angry with you, but I missed you so much.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I'll never leave you again. If you'll just try a little harder to be nice to me. And I'll try to do better, too. We must. We must! This was just silly and stupid.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: What is this?

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Oh no, not this. Not this, Wolfi! You're not to work on this ever again! I've decided.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: This is not his handwriting.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: No. I was assisting him. He asked me.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: He's not going to work on this anymore. It is making him ill. Please.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: But - but - but -

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: I regret we have no servants to show you out, Herr Salieri. Respect my wish and go.

Speaker: salieri
Dialogue: Madame, I will respect his. He asked me to stay here.

Speaker: constanze
Dialogue: Wolfi?  Wolfi?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Why? Why? Why? Why add to your misery by confessing to murder? You didn't kill him.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: No, you didn't!

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: I poisoned his life.

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: But not his body.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: What difference does that make?

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: My son, why should you want all Vienna to believe you a murderer? Is that your penance? Is it?

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: No, Father. From now on no one will be able to speak of Mozart without thinking of me. Whenever they say Mozart with love, they'll have to say Salieri with loathing. And that's my immortality - at last! Our names will  be tied together for eternity - his in fame and mine in infamy. At least it's better than the total oblivion he'd planned for me, your merciful God!

Speaker: vogler
Dialogue: Oh my son, my poor son!

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Don't pity me. Pity yourself. You serve a wicked God. He killed Mozart, not I. Took him, snatched him away, without pity. He destroyed His beloved rather than let a mediocrity like me get the smallest share in his glory. He doesn't care. Understand that. God cares nothing for the man He denies and nothing either for the man He uses. He broke Mozart in half when He'd finished with him, and threw him away. Like an old, worn out flute.

Speaker: local priest
Dialogue: The Lord giveth. The Lord taketh away. Blessed be the name of the Lord.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Why did He do it? Why didn't He kill me? I had no value. What was the use, keeping me alive for thirty-two years of torture? Thirty-two years of honours and awards.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Being bowed to and saluted, called 'distinguished - distinguished Salieri' - by men incapable of distinguishing! Thirty-two years of meaningless fame to end up alone in my room, watching myself become extinct. My music growing fainter, all the time fainter, until no one plays it at all. And his growing louder, filling the world with wonder. And everyone who loves my sacred art crying, Mozart! Bless you, Mozart.

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: Good morning, Professor! Time for the water closet. And then we've got your favourite breakfast for you - sugar-rolls.  He loves those. Fresh sugar-rolls.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Goodbye, Father. I'll speak for you. I speak for all mediocrities in the world. I am their champion. I am their patron saint. On their behalf I deny Him, your God of no mercy. Your God who tortures men with longings they can never fulfill. He may forgive me: I shall never forgive Him.

Speaker: old salieri
Dialogue: Mediocrities everywhere, now and to come: I absolve you all! Amen! Amen! Amen!
